--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Colin Green <cgreen@d...> wrote:
> Ok now I've woken up a bit... yes I agree with you here. Although 
one 
> point I would like to make is that this only works for direct 
encoding 
> schemes, NEAT is ok because a NEAT chromosome is a direct encoding 
of a 
> NN. If you start to consider indirect encoding (as in biology) then 
you 
> find that small changes in the genetic make up can result in large 
> changes in the phenotype. The solution is to compare phenotypes - 
which 
> is something I didn't take into a account in my own code which IS 
does 
> use indirect encoding.

That's a good point.  In the real world, chromosomes don't have sex, 
organisms do.  So the speciation mechanism for an indirect encoding 
scheme would probably need to base speciation on phenotype.

> >That is, in the second case, a given species could
> >have much more or much less topological difference
> >between its individuals.  This approach seems less
> >desirable to me, since it seems less
> >biologically-inspired.  You're enforcing an arbitrary
> >division of the population, rather than defining
> >species primarily by a distance function.
> >
> >  
> >
> Agreed.

Well, I say it seems that way, though I haven't tested any of this 
experimentally.

Does anyone else here have any thoughts on this?

> After reading this and having a think I do agree with you on this. 
So 
> going back to your original email, it's interesting that Ken used a 
> fixed N=1, or was this because the chromosome never became larger 
than 
> 20 in length? 

Right.  I'm especially interested to hear from those who've actually 
implemented their own version of NEAT and experimented with it.

Mat Buckland implemented NEAT with a minesweeper domain.  The 
book "AI Techniques for Game Programming" restates the speciation 
function, and the compatibility threshold, exactly as it is in Ken's 
paper(s).  Mat, do chromosomes grow larger than 20 genes in a typical 
minesweeper experiment?  If so, does your code adjust the 
compatibility threshold?

Joseph Reisinger experimented with Tic-Tac-Toe and a modular version 
of NEAT.  Did you normalize for chromosome size in your experiments, 
Joseph?  Or was N always set to 1 and the compatibility threshold 
value always set to either 3.0 or 4.0?

And Ken...in some of your other experiments, especially in the robot 
control domains, chromosomes grew to lengths greater than 20, didn't 
they?  Did you ever normalize for chromosome length in any 
experiments, or was N always equal to 1?  If so, wouldn't populations 
with larger chromosomes tend to have a much greater increase in the 
number of species?  Any thoughts on how the number of species affects 
the effectiveness of the algorithm?

Thanks,
Derek
